title: Who will win the 2020 California Democratic primary?
preds: THIS ESTIMATE DID NOT TAKE INTO CONSIDERATION THOSE VOTES ALREADY CAST INCLUDING THOSE FOR CANDIDATES WHO HAD SINCE DEPARTED THE RACE.

Going back to original estimate because  I went  to the polls place near where I live in California.  A clerk told me nearly one-third of the people in my precinct voted prior to the South Carolina primary.   It takes a few days for  a bounce to register in the polls.  Also, they voted prior  to Buttigieg and Styer dropping out.   Hence, the above events occurred too late to affect the primary.
Adjusting in light of Buttigieg dropping out. https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/01/us/politics/pete-buttigieg-drops-out.html

I extremized at 100 percent.  However, there have been some change in the last few days.   The two most recent polls taken before, and during the South Carolina primary (CBS and USA Today see link below)  have Bernie at 31 and 35 percent, respectively and Biden at 19 and 14 percent ,respectively.  To split the difference, Bernie was at 33 percent and Biden at 16.5 percent.    The last day of these polls was the date of the primary.  I suspect Biden's numbers will rise between 4 and 10 percent more due to the South Carolina bounce. So, let's say his numbers will rise by seven percent to about 23 percent.   Buttigieg and Styers both dropped out.  Buttigieg had about nine percent, and Styer had about 3 percent.  I think between 65 and 80 of Buttigieg's 9 percent  will go to Biden or about 6.5 percent (did that in my head so approx). and between 1/2 and 90 of Styers' 3 percent or about 2 percent will go to Joe.  
So Biden gets about 23+6.5+2 or about 32 percent to Bernie's 33 percent,  which makes the race very competitive.  I doubt Bernie's numbers will move much.  Let's see what tomorrow's polls bring.  https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2020/president/SuperTuesday.html
So much for Pete. Giving Biden his due after his impressive win in South Carolina.
Updating after the dust has settled in SC.

The crowd forecast, prediction market [1] and the FiveThirtyEight’s forecast for California primary [2] are overwhelming for Sanders.  Going 100% [1]  https://www.predictit.org/markets/detail/5823
[2]  https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/election-update-what-our-forecast-says-about-every-super-tuesday-state/
Bernie's on a roll despite Joe upping his campaign.
He's polling way ahead of the others.
All in for BS (since I've been way behind the consensus all along), not that it really matters to my score.
Updating based on 538 most recent analysis which shows an 88% chance that Sanders wins
Updating to reflect favorable polling data for Biden.
Bernie shows continued momentum in CA. Short of scandal or other major shakeup, he should win CA.

We are post-debate once again.  Biden did very well, and Bernie did not do too well.  The California primary is less than a week away, and voting has already started.  Bernie was plus approximately 14 points in all recent polls.  Biden cannot catch him but will narrow the gap.
Updating Sanders forecast upwards. He has a commanding lead in polls.

Solid, consistent, safe lead for Sanders in the polls:
https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2020/president/ca/california_democratic_primary-6879.html

Sanders is the overwhelming favourite here. His polling lead has held at 15-20% throughout the campaign and new polls today by Change Research and PBP gave him a lead of 19 points. A lead of 19 points gives him around a 90% chance of success. This is significantly more than the crowd who imply he only has a 73% chance of winning. Model - 90%
FiveThirtyEight - 87%
Exchange - 95%
Bernie is the nearest thing to a lock here given the polling and the 538 forecast.

Adjusting, but not sure I believe the polling. Some of the LV responses might be possible cross-over voters who in fact may not show up. Also, as we know CA is ~3 major ministates with different world views which may make it difficult to capture in a poll.

Buttigieg's campaign strategy of focusing one state at a time seems to be faltering, going from first to second to third and towards another low finish in South Carolina. This definitely takes the wind out of his sails and showcases his campaign's inability to multitask on several states at a time, this will only be exacerbated on Super Tuesday. Therefore, while polls tend to under predict his support, it remain infeasible for him to ultimately more than double his support in California while also campaigning in multiple other states.   Warren continues to inspire support on election day and polls tend to over predict her actual support, thereby she also isn't winning California. Bloomberg seems to be hovering and staying steady in the teens and due to his track record, debate performance and future debate performance  is unlikely to budge much further.  Biden's campaign did well enough in Nevada to keep it afloat, while possibly scoring a win in South Carolina, however his campaign is still floundering and hasn't been able to give the Super Tuesday states the attention necessary to win in key states. Therefore, Biden will also lose to the momentum that Bernie has behind him.
After the recent debate, and knowing this is a "must win" ...I feel momentum is currently in Sanders' favor.

Some adjusting after reflecting on some of the NV entrance polling (demographic breakdowns). CA non declared voters can get a D ballot, but one has to know the ropes how to do it. It will be interesting to see expected/actual votes from various demographic slices.
Clint Eastwood endorsed mayor of NYC Mike B.
Using 538 as a prior and adjusting towards Bernie due to Nevada results.

Adjusting forecast slightly per some more recent polling reported via 538. Biden appears to generally be in second place, significantly trailing Sanders.  https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-primary-d/california/
https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-primary-forecast/california/
Sanders ahead in polls. Bloomberg rising.

Bernie leads right now by about seven points, but South Carolina is four days prior and Biden leads. Also he did well in the debate last night.    So, seven points is outside the margin of error.  I guess Bernie's floor, which rises each time another progressive drops out, is about 25 percent as the race stands right now based upon the low numbers in the California polls.  His ceiling with the race as it is is about 30 percent for the same reason.  Biden's floor is about 20 percent, but there are a lot of voters who move between Bloomberg (8), Buttigieg(6), Warren(20), Klobachur (3) and Styers(2).     If he does well in South Carolina, he could get as much as one third of their support (8+6+20+3+2=39) or 13 points--or more. Hence, he could be at 33 percent to Bernie's ceiling of 30 percent.  Hence, Bernie is the current favorite but Biden is not yet out.
Expect joe biden will be out by then

The 2/20 Monmouth poll (A+ rating on FiveThirtyEight) on the California democratic primary shows Sanders at 24%, Biden at 17%, Bloomberg at 13%, Warren at 10%, Pete at 9%, and Klobuchar at 4%. Sanders should still be favored to win, but I believe the 2/19 democratic debate diminished Bloomberg's chances but increased Warren's chances. Biden has been trending downwards, and Pete has leveled off.
Bernie is leading in early polling in California by a substantial margin, and didn't lose by much in 2016.

Out of all of the primary races, this will probably be one of the tightest. Sanders will edge all of the candidates because of his stance on many social economic issues that directly impact many Californians. California has the city with the highest cost of living (San Francisco), and affordable living and access to jobs that pay a living wage will be a deciding factor in this election.  Both Sanders and Warren have the same stance on health care affordability  but i think Sanders has done a better job delivering his message.  Buttigieg will do extremely well with young voters and voters who (intellectually) relate to Buttigieg. I also think he will do well with moderate Democrats. I can see a fair amount of moderates voting for Mayor Pete and especially members of the military.  The "Dark Horse" in this race will be Michael Bloomberg. I think the tech industry, business elites, immigrants or children of immigrants will support Bloomberg. I think Michael's stance on immigration reform will attract a lot of voters.  The biggest outlier in this primary race is Elizabeth Warren. If she turns her campaign around and really hits the pavement with her message I can see her coming in a strong 4th. If she does then the outcome will be 
1. Mayor Pete 30%
2. Michael Bloomberg 27%
3. Bernie Sanders 23%
4. Elizabeth Warren 9%
5. Joe Biden 7%
6. Amy Klobuchar 4% Because Warren would most likely have the greatest impact on the Sanders campaign that any other.
Bernie is on the rise. People don't like Bloomberg more stuff coming out by the hour. Pete is still looking good. He was excellent o. The CNN Town hall

Sanders continues to poll well. ..Will update this again after the Dem. debate. https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-primary-d/california/ https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-primary-d/national/

Sanders polling very strongly, with the website 538 giving him a 68% chance at the moment. I have adjusted this upwards, demographics in this State favour him and i thing momentum from performance of states leading up to Super Tuesday increases the probability he wins the majority. Bloomberg's marketing blitz has propelled him into contention and he has a similar chance to Biden.

Bernie has been ahead in California for almost a month now, even before he started winning in Primary States and the latest poll after NH and Iowa indicate a surge/continuance of support around the crucial 25% mark and over, therefore Bernie has polling has been polling at winning number for a while. This support will only grow has Bernie is likely going to win Nevada and come in 2nd or 3rd in South Carolina, above other "popular" prospects like Buttigieg, Klobuchar and Warren. One should also not forget that Bernie has the highest level of support among Hispanic voters, which is a huge voting demographic in California and will likely propel him towards a victory there.  Warren's support in California has crumbled following her poor performance and the media's new found disregard for her. She will likely stay in the race till Super Tuesday, but her support levels on election day have been fairly consistent with poll projection at around 10%. It is unlikely she will find any momentum in Nevada or South Carolina and therefore will not be able to rally enough support to win California.  Biden's campaign will continue to falter in Nevada and will probably perform below expectations in South Carolina, as recent polls predict. California is also more inclined to vote progressive, so Biden's campaign in California will continue to lose ground to fellow moderates: Klobuchar, Buttigieg and Bloomberg.   Despite Klobuchar's surprise finish 3rd finish in NH, she isn't set up to do well in Nevada or South Carolina, thus her perceived "momentum" will be lost going into Super Tuesday, likely keeping her support in the low teens and thereby unable to win California.  The same can be said for Buttigieg, but Buttigieg's support thus far has been underrepresented in the polls and is being pushed and supported by many establishment democrats. Therefore it is possible for him to continue to increase support in California and that moderates start to rally around their "winnable" candidate. If so Buttigieg could possibly win California, but if not he will likely split the vote with other moderates.  Bloomberg also faces the same problem as many moderates and the SurveyUSA poll showing him with a surge of support in California should largely be discounted as A. it doesn't provide any margin of error or sample size and B. does phone polling which is far more likely to favor white and older people, as that is the demographic that is most likely going to pick up the phone. These people are more inclined to vote moderate and to watch network television, which has been blasted with Bloomberg adds. come election day, his real support levels will probably be in the teens, especially considering his problematic past which he is going to get blasted on during the debates. Therefore, will likely not be able to find the levels of support necessary to win California.
New poll this morning.  Bernie 18 points ahead of his nearest rival.
Some momentum from Bloomberg, but Sanders is the most likely to win.
According to 538 for CA, Sanders has a 7 in 10 (69%) chance of winning the most votes, much better than the second most likely winner, Biden, who has a 1 in 9 (11%) chance.
Battle of the billionaires makes sensr

Sanders is probably favourite to win Nevada. South Carolina is a very confused picture at the moment. Sanders has a strong lead in California polling & the state should be good for him, so although I don't like giving individuals high probabilities in these massive multiway primaries, maybe you have to here.  Biden is currently second in California polling & there is a small chance he gets a boost out of South Carolina, but his campaign is clearly heading in the wrong direction. Buttigeig so far has consistently overperformed his polling, hence me giving him the second highest chance. Bloomberg is the wild card, there's no base rate for someone throwing quite this much money at a nomination.
Voters react to the polls and previous results and it's currently Sanders v Buttigieg. I don't think Bloomberg appeals to the general Democrat.
Bernie has a 13 point lead in the latest poll.  I suspect a lot will change based upon what happens in South Carolina and Nevada.
All in for the Bern. Last I saw he had a double digit lead over Pocahontas.

I used the crowd forecasts and the prediction market [1] for this forecast, but scaled them to only the top 2 candidates since Bernie is an overwhelmingly likely winner. [1] https://www.predictit.org/markets/detail/5823/Who-will-win-the-2020-California-Democratic-primary
Just for fun. Guessing a bit all over the place.
Based on popularity of the candidates.

Bernie is currently out in front in available polls: https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-primary-d/california/ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_California_Democratic_primary https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/482847-where-the-2020-candidates-stand-on-super-tuesday
Coming soon, but no one is in CA yet. Pete seems to offer the young blood CA wants to see.  But as a gay person, can he win across the USA?
Moving up. Socialism is not a dirty word in California.

Its a four horse race, for now ppl see Bernie and Pete as President and Vice. That may well change in a few months with Bloomberg making a late charge, maybe even Bernie dropping out, who knows  But for now I think these two have the strongest numbers
Current polling data in California.  Money Bloomberg is spending on commercials in CA.
Sanders currently polling double his peers in California.
CA is a liberal state with some more traditional tenancies. The candidates further to the left are too radical for the Californian voters

Wow... this one got me thinking. Very initial, minimally researched, gut-check/impression. 
Having grown up in California (lived in the SF Bay Area and Los Angeles,) this is my baseline.  What is yet to be seen is:
- How Biden performs in SC.
- How Sanders performs in NV.
- Who drops out. This is a critical primary that'll inform several subsequent forecasts.
I think Mayor Pete and Bernie are the only viable candidates left that have a chance in California. I think the former has a somewhat better appeal in CA than the latter

The vote will still be split between more liberal and more moderate candidates by the time of the California primary.  Given that CA is a relatively liberal state, I give the combination of Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren a slight edge.  Mike Bloomberg's strength would be in providing a more electable alternative to both the liberals and to more centrist candidates like Klobuchar, Biden and Buttigieg, but I don't believe that the panic among the centrists will have set in yet, especially among the more liberal CA voters.
Based on media coverage in the UK
Sanders is the obvious energized base choice, however it’s going to be a lower than expected turnout which will hurt Pete.
In the end, his recognition will be the reason.
Initial forecast. Will revise once we see a crowd forecast and some polling.

Californians are likely leaning towards the left side and of the few that have a chance,  I think Sanders hits their spot. But if they focus on who can beat Trump, Bloomberg has a good chance sbx by then, voters will know his name. Buttigieg might have momentum so I give him a nonzero chance.
